dataset.title: Characterization of Cucumber mosaic cucumovirus associated with banana mosaic disease by combined approaches

creator.organizationName: Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology, National Taiwan University
Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology, National Taiwan University
Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology, National Taiwan University
Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology, National Taiwan University

abstract.para: 12 Cucumber mosaic virus (CMV) isolates associated with banana mosaic disease (BMD) in Taiwan were collected and characterized. From the symptoms induced on banana by these CMV isolates, three symptom types were grouped. Members within each banana symptom type also induced similar symptoms on N. glutinosa. It suggested that members within each banana symptom type do share similar common biological prosperities in inducing symptoms on banana and N. glutinosa. Double stranded RNA analysis revealed that the differential symptoms between groups are not related to the presence of satellite RNA. On the contrary, although cowpea is good hosts in CMV grouping based on the ability of CMV in cowpea systemic infection, the grouping is irrelevant in banana symptom inducing. Sequence analysis revealed that the systemic infection of CMV in cowpea reflected in their CP sequence. Phylogenetic analysis also revealed that CMV associated with BMD did not cluster together and were randomly assigned into distinctive CMV subgroup. It indicated several distinctive CMV strains all have the ability to infect banana which will complicate the disease managements. Interestingly, phylogenetic analysis using 89 CMV reported around the world reveled that in contrast to the currently known CMV subgroup IA , IB and II, our collected CMV form a new subgroup within subgroup I, and two new distinctive CMV subgroups within subgroup I were also resolved. Our analysis also pointing out that subgroup IB of CMV is actually phylogeneticlly unresolved and grouping of CMV may need to be further improved.

contact.organizationName: Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology, National Taiwan University

section.title: Samples collection and isolation of virus
section.para: The diseased banana leaves with differential symptoms were collected from southern Taiwan. These samples were checked by ELISA using antibody against CMV before isolation (35). The CMV were isolated from infected plants by rubbing the sap extracted from the infected plant to Chenopodium amaranticolor, followed by three times of consecutive single local-lesion isolations, and then maintained and propagated in N. glutinosa. The CMV were transmitted from N. glutinosa to healthy banana plantlets (about 15 cm in height) by cotton aphid (Aphis gossypii ). The aphids were pre-starvation for 2 hr in petri dishes, and then fed on CMV infected N. glutinosa leaves. These aphids were allowed acquisition access for 30 sec~1 min, and then were transferred to banana leaves for overnight. The bananas were then sprayed with imidacloprid insectcide.

section.title: RNA extraction
section.para: Total RNA were extracted by Trizol® reagent (Invitrogen, Life technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA) following the manufacturer’s instructions, and dissolved in 20 μl DEPC treated water after briefly air dry.
Amplification of CMV CP gene by RT-PCR

The RT-PCR reaction were essential the same as described (19). Nucleic acids extracted from CMV infected plants were used as template for cDNA synthesis. First strand cDNA synthesis was initiated with primer CP-CMV RE (5’- GCT GGA TGG ACA ACC CGT TC -3’, complementary to nucleotide positions 2011- 2030 of CMV RNA3) by using M-MLV reverse transcriptase (Promega, Madison, WI, USA). Synthesized cDNAs were used as a template DNA, and the primer pair CP-CMV RE and CP-CMV (a degenerated primer corresponding to nucleotide positions 1153-1172; 5’-CTT TYT CAT GGA TGC TTC TC-3’, Y =A or T) with Taq (Promega) polymerase were used in PCR for 35 cycles. Cycling conditions were: one cycle of 95℃ for 5 min; 35 cycles of 94℃ for 1 min, 55℃ for 30 sec, 72℃ for 1 min; one cycle of 72℃ for 10 min.

section.title: Double stranded (ds) RNA extraction and analysis
section.para: Total RNA were extracted from 1g of infected bananas and LiCl were added to final concentration of 2.1 M, and kept at 4oC overnight. The supernatant were collected after centrifuge at 12000 g for 15 minutes. 2.5 Volume of ethanol was added and centrifuge at 12000 g for 15 minutes to precipitate the dsRNA. The pellets were dissolved in 30 μl DEPC water. To avoid single stranded RNA contamination, 2 μl of sodium chloride (5 M) and 0.5 μl RNaseA (20 μg/ml) were added, and incubated at 37oC for 30 min. Then 3.6 μl of SDS (10%) were added and incubated at 37oC for 15 minutes. The solution were extracted once with equal volume of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1), and transfer the aqueous phase to a clean mircocentrifuge tube. The residual RNA were precipitated by adding 2.5 volume of ethanol and 1/10 volume of sodium acetate (3 M). The pellets were dissolved in 15 μl DEPC water. The dsRNA were separated on 1% TAE agarose gel.

section.title: Amplification of CARNA 5 by RT-PCR
section.para: The primer, CMV-SAT-LRE (5’- GCT GGA TGG ACA ACC CGT TCG GG T CCT G- 3’), was designed with 8 nucleotides complementary sequences to the most 3’ termini of all published CMV satellite RNAs and followed by CP-CMV-RE sequence at its 5’ region. The CMV-SAT-LRE was used for first strand cDNA synthesis. The CMV-SAT-LFR (5’- CTT TTT CAT GGA TGC TTC TCG TTT TGT TTG -3’) was designed with 10 identical sequences to all published 5’ satellite RNAs and followed by CP-CMV sequences at 5’ region. The CMV-SAT-LFR was used for second strand cDNAs synthesis. The extracted dsRNA (from isolate 22 infected N. glutinosa) were used as template to synthesize cDNA. The cDNAs were synthesized as described. Synthesized cDNAs were used as a template DNA, and the primers CP-CMV RE, CP-CMV were used for PCR amplification with Taq (Promega) polymerase. The PCR cycling conditions were: one cycle of 95℃ for 5 min; 35 cycles of 95℃ 30 sec, 50℃ for 30 sec and 72℃ 20 sec; and one cycle of 72℃ for 10min.

section.title: Cloning and sequencing
section.para: The amplified fragments were cloned into pGEM®-T easy (Promega) by incubating with T4 DNA ligase (Promega) overnight at 4℃, then transformed into Escherichia coli (Top 10). Nucleotide sequences of the cloned cDNAs were determined by use of ABI Prism DNA sequencer 310 or 377 (Applied Biosystems, Foster city, CA)

section.title: Phylogenetic analysis
section.para: Multiple sequences alignment were performed by CLUSTAL X (1.83) (31). Phylogenetic analyses were inferred by maximum parsimony (MP) and neighbor joining (NJ) methods. MP and NJ was used by PAUP* 4.0b 10 (31). In MP analysis, we conducted heuristic searches with 1000 random addition replicases, and tree bisection-reconnection branch swapping; and each replicate 10 trees were saved. An HKY85 nucleotide substitution model was analyzed in NJ analysis. Both of NJ and MP analysis branch support were estimated with 1000 replicated bootstrap analyses.

dataTable.entityDescription: Grouping of CMV by symptoms on differential host

attribute.attributeDefinition: Symptoms induced by CMV strains on bananas can be grouped into three major types. Type I induced severe green mosaic with deformed leaves (I-d) or slender leaves (I-s), type II induced yellow mosaic with necrosis (II), and type III induced severe green mosaic without deformed leaves (III).

Symptoms induced by CMV strains on N. glutinosa can be grouped into three major types: Isolates within group A induced severe green mosaic with parkling and leaf distortion (A) or fern leaf (A-f), group B induced severe green mosaic with leaf necrosis (B), and group C induced mild mottling without leaf distortion (C).

Symptoms induced by CMV strains on cowpea can be grouped into 2 major groups. Group L (L) induced local lesion on inoculated leaves and will not systematically infect cowpea, and group S (S) can systematically infect cowpea.
